Posts.Content: Hi there, my situation is slightly different to yours but I have 2 young boys, ages 8 and 3.  We were all living very happily in Gibraltar when this happened and I was sent back to UK for treatment as the standards are better here.  I am having to live apart from my children and stay with my Mum, which is difficult at times, having just turned 40! I see my children whenever we can..they come here and I have recently been there.  But you are right, it is hard work looking after them when I am feeling rough.  My 8 years old is fine but the 3 years old hasn't got a clue whats going on.  Half the time he thinks I live in the computer because I talk to him on skype! As Kate mentioned above...take all the help that is offered to you, especially when you are feeling at your worst.  Do you have a good support network?  It isn't easy because they don't really understand what is going on, but if you can get help when its needed that will be hugely helpful. Don't worry about having to give up breastfeeding earlier than you would have liked too...it is a shame you had to but you have to put yourself first right now and you should be proud that at least you did breast feed for a while and gave your baby the most wonderful start in life! I hope all continues to go well for you.  Big hugs, Sarah xxxxxxxxxx
Posts.Title: Coping with cancer treatment AND young kids!

Posts.Content: Hi there,  I am due to have a mastectomy in approx 3 weeks time (I had chemo first).  I have been advised to have delayed reconstruction but this is mainly because I am having radiotherapy 2 months after op and apparently radio can affect the implant.  So I am having reconstruction in 6 months time and I am also going to opt for removal of my other breast.  They are going to reconstruct that one at the same time. I too have large boobs (32 FF) so I am going to ask to be a nice C cup when I have my new ones! Hope all goes well with the rest of your treatment.  Let me know how your reconstruction goes! love Sarah xxxxxxxxx
Posts.Title: Immediate or delayed recon?

Posts.Content: Hi girls...I think it must just depend on surgeons.  I am having mx next Friday and I wanted immediate reconstruction but I am not allowed to have it because I am having radiotherapy.  He said the radiotherapy affects the implant somehow?? So, I have to wait 2 months post surgery before I can start radiotherapy and then 6 months post radiotherapy before I can have reconstruction!  Seem to be forever waiting for something.  Still, as long as it gets rid of this bloody thing I don't care! I've also had some confusion re. when to have expander fitted prior to recon.  A friend has told me that her plastics consultant said she should have had it before radiotherapy and was apparently 'not happy' that this hadn't been done, but my surgeon said that neither him or the plastics consultants are happy to put an expander in before radiotherapy???? Who knows!!!  I guess we just have to go with what we are advised individually...but it is confusing when you hear conflicting advice! Wishing you all well..love and hugs Sarah xxx

Posts.Title: How long have you had to wait between surgery and "specimen" results...

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, I was diagnosed with breast cancer yesterday after finding a small lump approx 4 weeks ago.  It has been an awful time.  We have been living abroad as my husband is in the RAF, so I was referred to Birmingham hospital for ultrasound and biopsy.  We had to spend all weekend in a hotel away from our children, friends and family whilst we awaited my results.  It was such a shock to be told I have a grade 3 cancer that is 2.5 cms.  We were referred to a hospital nearer to my mums house so had to drive for 3 hours to get there, eventually arriving late last night.  We have hardly slept and I can't stop crying.  I am also missing my children as they are being looked after by my mum in our house abroad until next week.  I am also worried because since the biopsy was done by lump has become much bigger and sore.  I have a consultant appt on Thursday and the plan is the start chemotherapy as soon as possible, then have the lump removed then possible radiotherapy!  From reading other peoples posts I realise I am not alone in feeling like this but just felt I needed to put something on here.  I am especially worried that the lump feels bigger and just want it taken out.  I would appreciate any advice and guidance. Thank you x

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed - very scared and emotional

Posts.Content: Hi Libby,  I had this exact discussion with the nurse yesterday whilst having my 3rd FEC.  The Dexamethazone was causing me to not only have a bright red face for 3 days following chemo but I couldn't sleep and had an awful headache which only went away after I stopped taking them after day 3. Her advice to me was to not stop taking it  as it works well with the other anti sickness drugs but try altering my dose.  I was taking 2 twice a day but she said I could try taking 1 twice a day or just take the full dose but for 2 days.  I have decided to take 1 twice a day.  I took one this morning and although I still have the bright red face I don't have a headache..which is a bonus.  Have a chat with them and see if they recommend the same thing. I also spoke to my oncologist re. blurred vision and that my eye sight felt like it had deteriorated, because I was considering having an eye test, but she said not to as it is a side effect of the chemo.  She said if my eyes were gritty as well she would prescribe me some eye drops, but they're not gritty, just watery and blurry. I hope apart from these annoying symptoms you are not feeling too bad.  Speak soon Sarah xxxx
Posts.Title: Has anyone stopped taking steroids?

Posts.Content: Hi there, my situation is very similar to yours.  I have a grade 3, 30mm lump.  I have been having chemo first since Sept.  I started on FEC but after 3 lots they did a scan and said lump hadn't shrunk so they changed me to Docetaxel.  Unfortunately I only had one of those because I had an allergic reaction to it so I am now on weekly Paclitaxel. The reasons they gave me for doing chemo first were; to shrink the tumor so that surgery is less invasive and to check I am on the correct chemo (that works).  They like to monitor the effect of the chemo and can change it if it isn't doing what they want it to do.  They said because I was relatively young at diagnosis (39) they preferred to do it this way, but I know other people of a similar age who have had their lump removed first so i don't really know how they make their decisions. I have 2 more weekly chemo's to go before next scan then they are probably going to do the op regardless of the result.  My lump feels the same size to me but Onc feels that it has become softer which is apparently a good sign.  To be honest, I just want this bloody lump out although I can see why they kept it in. My onc also told me the other day that sometimes the lump itself might not shrink but the cancer can still have been destroyed, but they don't know this until you have had op.  I hope all goes well with you, keep in touch as it would be lovely to hear how you are getting on with it. Sending big hugs xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx

Posts.Content: Hi there,  My Mum also had exactly the same kind of reaction after she had her mastectomy, 8 years ago.  She was waiting for her dressing to be removed and it felt uncomfortable and itchy...when they finally took it off at the end of the day she was covered in blisters and the skin was very red and angry.  It cleared up relatively quickly once the dressing was off and the air got to it. I'm sure people are only usually allergic to certain types of dressings eg. elastoplast (like me and my mum), there should always be alternative dressings available for people who are allergic. Make sure, if you are having a further op that they are aware of your allergic reaction so they can use something else.  There should be something better for you than just steristrips. Love Sarah xxxxxxx
Posts.Title: Allergic to dressing, anyone else ?

Posts.Content: Hi there...Welcome to the community.  I have found the support I have received on here to be amazing.  There is always someone out there who has been through the same or similar to you, so loads of advice available.   I was diagnosed in September and started chemo very quickly (my surgery will follow the chemo).  I think it pretty much depends on which chemo drugs you have, as to whether your hair will fall out, but most of the commonly used ones do cause your hair to either fall out or thin. I opted to use the cold cap to keep mine.  I had long hair but was advised to get it cut to at least a bob, which is what I have done.  I have had 4  treatments so far and I have kept most of my hair.   It has thinned on the crown but I can cover it easily with an alice band.  The condition is still good but they advised me to use Simple shampoo and conditioner.  Now, the only thing is, the cold cap is a horrible thing to wear.  It maintains your head at -4 degrees for 30 min before chemo starts, during chemo and for anything from 45 mins to 2 hours following chemo (depending which drug you are having).  You have ice on your head when they take it off and it feels very uncomfortable, but I have kind of got used to it now.  However, it is not easy and I sometimes wish I hadn't bothered and just let my hair fall out, but I kind of feel i have come to far to stop now! Whatever you decide to do, I would advise you cut your hair sooner rather than later as it will give you time to get used to it.  You don't have to go for a complete crop...do it in stages and see how it goes. Sending you god luck and hugs and hope all goes well once you start your treatment.  Let me know how you get on.  Love Sarah xxxxx
Posts.Title: New to all this .....

Posts.Content: Hi flower20 Sorry you didn't get the results you wanted but don't give up yet!  If they are going to take all of your nodes out that is a good thing and am I correct in thinking you had scans a few weeks ago that looked good, with no signs of spread?  Can't remember if you have had chemo yet but if not then you have that still to come and any cancer cells in your body will be zapped! I have my results tomorrow, following my mastectomy and full node clearance and I am really nervous about it.  Trying to prepare myself but feel so anxious. At least my appt is early so don't have to wait too long. Just remember, they have removed your breast and therefore all the cancer that was in it and now they are going to remove all of your lymph nodes as a precaution too!  It is unlikely they will all have cancer in them (My BC nurse told me that the other day). Your treatment is still ongoing and you will beat this.  I know how you feel about losing a boob..it's definitely weird, especially when you have one huge one (like me) left over...but we can have reconstruction for this later and get back to our old selves.  Sending you loads of positive vibes...just let yourself get over each hurdle, one at a time.  It does seem so unfair when you are so young (I was 39 when diagnosed), but we are strong and can fight this! Posts.Content: Hi there, I used the cold cap throughout my chemo, I had 3x fec and 3x paclitaxel.  I found that I had worse headaches when I was on the fec but I think it was the steroid tablets that i took alongside it.  When I stopped them the headaches were not so bad.  I didn't need to take all the steroids with the paclitaxel and I didn't suffer with any headache at all.  The first 15 mins of the cold cap made my head feel a bit tight but after that it was fine. I finished my chemo last week and I have pretty much a full head of hair, slightly thinner but apart from that it's fine.  I lost a bit of hair on my crown after first chemo but that was because cap didn't fit properly.  They changed the size the next time and by the time I had finished chemo my hair had grown back on my crown. The cold cap is not nice but I am so glad I continued with it because I still feel I look like me.  I wish your friend all the best with her treatment and hope she gets on well with the cold cap.   If her headaches continue advise her to speak to her oncology nurse specialist or one of the nurses at the chemo unit.  When I did they told me to reduce my steroids and that did help. Love and hugs Sarah xxxxxx
Posts.Title: Cold Cap...Severe headaches????

Posts.Content: Hi there.....is it the hand on the side you had your lymph nodes removed?  If so, it could just be swelling that can accumulate because of the clearance.  Sometimes people have to have it removed (my mum did).  I would ring either your GP or your surgeon and explain that you are worrying about it and they may be able to put your mind at rest.  If not, ring the helpline on here because they are really good.  I think this horrible disease make you worry about everything so I'm sure the GP or surgeon will completely understand that you need some reassurance.  Thinking of you xxxxxx
